chapterTitle: Some Lessons From Capital Market History

columns.text: An efficient market is characterized as a market wherein all information about stocks and bonds are provided for free and all transmissions are instant. This means that in an efficient market, no one is at a profit nor at a loss.

NPVs or net present values are the difference between the initial investment and the present cash flow value. In normal market, there are discrepancies between these two values. There are projects that have higher initial costs with lower present cashflow value while there are others that are the opposite. These discrepancies are what investors use in order to make a profit. They can sell those that do not generate profit and they can buy those that generate profit. This is why in a an efficient market, no profit is made since there are no discrepancies between the investment value and the cashflow which means there is no opportunity to make a profit.

In this problem, we will explain why one of the characteristics of an efficient market is that its investments have zero net present value (NPV).

***Let's get started, shall we?***

First, we will define what is an efficient market. An **efficient market** is one in which everyone receives the same information flawlessly, totally, quickly, and at no cost. If markets are efficient, then there is no way to "beat" the market since there are no cheap or overpriced assets on the market.

Then, we will define that is NPV. **Net present value (NPV)** is a technique for determining the current worth of all future cash flows throughout the full investment's lifetime. So that a project may be approved, the NPV criterion is that the investment must generate a positive cash flow in excess of the investment cost. If the circumstance is the opposite, then it must be rejected.

When it comes to assets, investors typically either purchase or sell. A positive net present value is generated when an investor purchases assets with the goal of increasing the returns on their purchase. However, it may sell assets that are losing money, resulting in a negative net present value  for the investor. Whenever there is a positive NPV, the values of the assets have a tendency to gain owing to the bidding process of the investor. This causes the NPV to decrease back to zero whenever there is a positive NPV. When the NPV is negative, the values of the asset go down, which causes the NPV to go up until it reaches zero again. Consequently, in a market with efficient characteristics, investments generate zero NPV.
